titleStmt.title: The confession and execution of the prisoners at Tyburn on Wednesday the 11th of this instant June 1679. Viz. Robert Bareford for a burglary. Benjamin Dauforn for pocket-picking. Henry Senson for a burglary. Richard Capel of felony. Being a satisfactory account of all their crimes for which they suffered, the rest being most graciously reprieved. With an account of their deportment in prison, and at the place of execution, with several other remarkable circumstances. As also a true narration of a notorious robbery committed on the house of Sir Tho. Nightingal of Langham in the county of Essex, by five persons, in Thursday-night the 5th of this instant June, two of which are now taken, and in Newgate.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The Execution of the Pri≈øoners at Tyburn.
div.p: THE mi≈øerable Cata≈øtrophies of the≈øe deplored Wretches, who≈øe ≈øad ends (though well de≈øerved by rea≈øon of their Crimes) I here purpo≈øe to relate, the which may ≈øure amu≈øe the World, and rou≈øe ≈øecure Sinners from their drou≈øine≈øs, le≈øt dreadful Fate awake 'em, when too late, only to view their ≈øure and certain Death.

The fir≈øt in this Di≈øa≈øter was Robert Bareford, for committing a Burglary upon a Hou≈øe in St. Katherines, commonly called by the Name of the Seven Stars; and thence felloniou≈øly bearing away, contrary to the e≈øtabli≈øhed Laws of this Nation, and His Maje≈øties Crown and Dignity, ≈øeveral Parcels, as well Hou≈øhold-goods as Money, to a con≈øiderable value. Part of the Goods being found upon him he was committed: and in Court the Fellony and Burglary proved, he received Sentence, and on Wedne≈øday being the 11th of this in≈øtant June, 1679 ≈øuffered accordingly at Tyburn. His penitence, as to outward appearance, ≈øeemed more than commonly from ≈øuch Offenders can be expected

The next of whom we ≈øhall treat, that by his evil cour≈øes
brought him≈øelf to this untimely and di≈øgraceful end, was Richard Capel; a young Man, but an old Offender; having been once burnt in the Hand at Surry A≈ø≈øizes: And in the late Conflagration of New Pri≈øon, he then being Pri≈øoner there, e≈øcaped thence in the Hurry and Throng of People a≈ø≈øembled at that time for the extingui≈øhing of the Fire: of which Fire I ≈øuppo≈øe few are ignorant. He not being content with his liberty, fell to his old Employment afre≈øh; for, as our Engli≈øh Proverb more fully denotes, Impo≈ø≈øible 'tis to wi≈øh an Ethiopian white, ≈øo accu≈øtomed Crimes do ≈øeldome leave indulged Sinners; for the≈øe often warnings were not ≈øufficient to prevail upon his ≈øerious thoughts, but following ≈øtill tho≈øe fatal Tracks that tend to Death and Hell, at la≈øt he was En≈ønared in his Devices: For one Evening, ≈øomewhat late, he did commit a Fellony in a Cooks Hou≈øe in Blackamore-≈øtreet, bearing thence as much Pewter as he could conveniently carry; being met and ≈øtopped by the Watch, he told them he had it in ≈øuch a place, but the people being called up would not own it; but after ≈øome time they, by the Marks, found the right Owner; whereupon he was committed, and after ≈øentenced, and this day executed. His Behaviour in Pri≈øon after his condemnation was more than ordinarily pennitent, confe≈ø≈øing and bewailing his former lude and vicious cour≈øes; for it is commonly ≈øeen that Death's unavoidable approach often ≈øtartles the harde≈øt Sinner. At the place of Execution he de≈øired all to take warning by his untimely end, and that they timely would repent.

Benjamin Dauforn was the next; for that Artificial Trade of Pocket-picking; and 'tis the more remarkable by rea≈øon he dur≈øt venture upon that unlawful Art in the Grand
place this Nation has ≈øo long been plea≈øed to build „Äà‚óä„Äâ Seats of Ju≈øtice in; I mean We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall: for on „Äà‚óä„Äâ 18th of May la≈øt pa≈øt, he unlawfully took a Pur≈øe out of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Gentlemans Pocket, and in it 4 or 5 pounds, it being then Term-Time: He being pur≈øued, threw down the Money in the Corner of a Window; but notwit≈øtanding he was Apprehended and Committed for the ≈øame: and it appearing upon his Tryal that he was an old Offender, he was Sentenced, and this day Executed. He likewi≈øe at the place of Execution, when he ≈øaw all hopes of pardon vain, and that Death's fatal A≈øpects were ≈øo dreadful, ≈øhed abundance of tears for his former ≈øins, and begged eternal mercy for his Soul.

The next, in order, was Henry Sea≈øon, for robbing a Per≈øon of Quality in Che≈øwick, and felloniou≈øly bearing away a Flitch of Bacon, two Kettles, and other things, he having been an old Effender heretofore, was ≈øentenced, and accordingly executed. He much bewailed his Offences during his being in the Hold, and ≈øaid, That bad Company had enticed him to act that, and many other Exploits; but that he hoped for mercy from above, although he could expect none here below, by rea≈øon of the hainou≈øne≈øs of his former Offenees; and he was exceeding penitent to the la≈øt, de≈øiring the Spectators to ≈øupplicate Omnipotence for mercy on his Soul, when he ≈øhould appear before the Dread Tribunal, to an≈øwer for his wilful and heedle≈øs Sin, and former Offences.
There were ≈øeaven more Condemned to Die, but received a mo≈øt gracious Reprieve, in expectation of their Amendment for the future.

And now one would imagine the≈øe ≈øo often repeated Examples of offended ju≈øtice ≈øhould re≈øtrain offending mi≈øcreants; but Deaths grim terrors ≈øeem but ≈øhadows till his ≈øure approach do undeceive their blinded Judgments; as may in this be ≈øeen the narration of which I ≈øhall here unto Annex by rea≈øon Crimes de≈øerving death may neare≈øt ≈øute with its intendancy: The which narration is of a notorious Robery committed by five per≈øons, (two of which are now in New-gate) who breaking into the Hou≈øe of Sir Thomas Nightingall of Langham, In the County of E≈ø≈øex, on Thur≈øday-night the 5th. of June 1679. and bearing away from thence in Money, Jewels and Plate the value of ≈øeven hundred pounds.

div.head: The Account of the Felony and Burglary Committed at and upon the hou≈øe of Sir Tho. Nightingal, at Langham, in the County of E≈ø≈øex, on Thur≈øday the 6th of this In≈øtant June, 1679. the manner as followeth.
div.p:
THE ≈øaid Sir Thomas his Son entertaining in his Service, as his Footman or Attendant, one Tho. Cotten (commonly called Longboy by rea≈øon of excellent skill in running) who, for his many mi≈ødemeanours, and offences, his ≈øaid Ma≈øter thought fit to di≈øcharge of his ≈øaid imployment and ≈øervice; who lying up and down the ≈øaid Town of Langham, could not content him≈øelf but mu≈øt needs though unadvi≈øedly, ≈øpread ≈øome ≈øini≈øter Reports of Sir Thomas, the Father of his ≈øaid Ma≈øter, for which he was taken and ≈øtrip'd of his Livery, the which inraged him ≈øo far as to vow revenge, for ≈øo (as he termed it) grievous Affront within a Fortnights ≈øpace; upon which he immediately
made to London, where being arrived he went to a certain Vintners hou≈øe with whom he had been formerly acquainted: The Vintner, at the fir≈øt ≈øight of him, demanded why he went without his Livery he was formerly wont to wear; upon which the ≈øaid Cotten told him how his Ma≈øter had u≈øed him, and aggravated the Circum≈øtances to an extreme degree: Whereupon the Vintner demanded whether he would pa≈øs by ≈øuch an Affront without any endeavours to requite it in ≈øome nature or other, who an≈øwered no, for he had already vowed revenge: The Vintner demanded whether the ≈øaid Sir Tho. Nightingal had not any Park of Dear adjoyning to his hou≈øe, a ≈øymbolical meaning u≈øed by ≈øuch kind of per≈øons, but the ≈øaid Cotten not well under≈øtanding the interpretation ≈øimply an≈øwered no, but that he had only two Does feeding before his hou≈øe: Whereupon the Vintner ask'd him more plainly whether he had ≈øtore of Silver, Gold, or Jewels, in his pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, who told him he had to a confiderable vallue; whereupon they agreed to go down together in a Calla≈øh or Charriot, drawn with one Hor≈øe, the which they put in execution; and being arrived at the place afore≈øaid ≈øet up at a little Inn or Ale-hou≈øe, ≈øome di≈øtance from the afore≈øaid Sir Thomas his hou≈øe, where drinking for ≈øome time they went to view the Inlets and Conveniences of the ≈øaid Sir Thomas his hou≈øe, and although the afore≈øaid Cotten was as conveniently de≈øigned as po≈ø≈øible, yet was he ob≈øerved and taken notice of by ≈øeveral of the Inhabitants of the place who were formerly acquainted with him; the which, after the Robbery, rai≈øed the fir≈øt ≈øu≈øpicion of his being a Party in the ≈øame; but the Vintner and he, after having taken a ≈øerious view, returned again to London, and ≈øending for a Company of dexterous Fellows, skill'd
in that Employment, they altogether after ≈øome merriment agreed to go down and break up the hou≈øe, the ≈øaid Cotton de≈øcribing to them the manner order and Affairs of the ≈øame, as al≈øo where the Plate, Moneys, Jewels, and the like were di≈øpo≈øed of, where on Thur≈øday-night, the day afore≈øaid, they entered in and carryed away to the value of 700 pounds in Plate and Moneys without being di≈øcovered by any of the Family. The number that effected the ≈øame were only five, viz. Thomas Cotten, and the Vintner now in Newgate, with three others not yet taken in this pernicious Intreague. There was one thing worth ob≈øerving, having broke into a Clo≈øet, they found among≈øt the re≈øt ≈øix (or thereabouts) Bottles of Mumm, the which Sir Thomas had re≈øerved for his own drinking; the≈øe they in a bravado mu≈øt needs drink off before they would depart, after which they ha≈øted to London, and at the Vintners hou≈øe ≈øhared their Prey. The next morning Sir Thomas finding him≈øelf robbed, and con≈øidering the ≈øtrength of the place thought that the Thieves mu≈øt have Intellegence from ≈øome that were well acquainted with the hou≈øe whereupon he began to call to mind the threatnings of the afore≈øaid Cotten: As likewi≈øe having intellegence by ≈øome of the Neighbours, that he had been lately in the Town; where upon ≈øending up with all ≈øpeed to London, he was ≈øea≈øed in his Lodging and being carryed before a Magi≈øtrate he confe≈ø≈øed his accomplices and the contrivance of the Robery as before recited whereupon a Con≈øtable being ≈øent the Vintner was taken in his own hou≈øe but the other three e≈øcaped; for this Fact the ≈øaid Thomas Cotten And the ≈øaid Vintner were committed to New-gate on Munday the 9th. of this in≈øtant June 1679. In order to their Tryals &c.
